item.title: After Flash Floods in Spain, Rescuers and Residents Face a Grim Scene
item.description: Others are still missing, though how many remains unclear. Rescuers feared finding more bodies, the defense minister said.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola, José Bautista and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Oscar Del Pozo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: U.S. Officials Try to Advance Israel’s Cease-Fire Talks With Hezbollah and Hamas
item.description: William Burns, the C.I.A. director, made a last-ditch attempt to move Gaza talks along before U.S. elections next week.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: People searching through rubble at the site of an Israeli strike in Beit Lahia, in the northern Gaza Strip, on Wednesday.

item.title: Iranian Officials Threaten Retaliation for Israeli Strikes
item.description: It was unclear how or when Iran plans to respond, or whether the rhetoric could be bluster. Iranian officials had downplayed the damage of Israel’s last attack.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Gen. Ali Fadavi, Deputy Chief of the Islamic Revolution Guards Corps, on Thursday indicated that Iran intends to retaliate to Israel’s recent attacks.

item.title: Germany Shuts 3 Iranian Consulates Over Execution of German-Iranian
item.description: The rare step of closing the consulates reflected German protests over the execution of Jamshid Sharmahd, an outspoken opponent of the Iranian regime.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: The Iranian Embassy in Berlin on Tuesday.

item.title: Spain Flash Floods: Scenes From the Deluge
item.description: Flash flooding across Spain killed more than 150 people after torrential rain left towns and villages submerged and turned streets into rivers.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A street in Valencia, Spain, on Wednesday.

item.title: North Korea, in the Spotlight Over Ukraine, Launches a Long-Range Missile
item.description: The launch, into waters west of Japan, came shortly after the United States and South Korea criticized the North for sending troops to join Russia’s war.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: South Korean news coverage of North Korea’s missile test on Thursday, using file footage from an earlier launch.

item.title: In China, Comedy Is Giving Women a Voice. But Can Men Take a Joke?
item.description: Comedy has become a way for women to skewer China’s gender inequality. Some men aren’t happy about it.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang

item.title: The World Series Was Big in Japan. The TV Ratings Prove It.
item.description: Shohei Ohtani, the Dodgers’ superstar, drove massive interest for the World Series in Japan, where more than 15 million people watched each of the first two games.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Richard A. Brooks/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Dodgers fans cheering at a bar in Tokyo on Thursday.

item.title: Strike on Gaza Hospital Destroys UN Supplies, Palestinian Officials Say
item.description: Israeli troops had withdrawn from Kamal Adwan Hospital after arresting most of the medical staff. The Israeli military said it was “unaware of a strike” there.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: Wounded Palestinians being treated this week at Kamal Adwan Hospital in Jabaliya, in the northern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Typhoon Kong-rey Lashes Taiwan With Powerful Winds and Rain
item.description: The storm was the most powerful tropical cyclone to hit Taiwan in nearly 30 years, the government said. At least two people were killed and hundreds were injured.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien, Alexandra E. Petri and Judson Jones

item.title: Torture Is a Russian Tactic in Occupied Ukraine, Civilians Say
item.description: Moscow is employing a variety of tactics, including torture and forced Russian citizenship, to try to obliterate Ukrainian identity, former detainees and human rights groups say.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians at a registration center in Sumy, Ukraine, after arriving from Russian-occupied areas.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Devastating floods in Spain.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Severe rain and flooding caused devastation in Paiporta, Spain.

item.title: Sorrow and Pain in a Spanish Town Devastated by Flooding
item.description: More than 60 people were killed as floodwaters roared through Paiporta. “We are alive,” one woman said. “But we have lost everything.”
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Residents of Paiporta, Spain, a town on the outskirts of Valencia, trying to clean a flood-ravaged street on Thursday.

item.title: Mexico’s New President, Claudia Sheinbaum, Faces First Major Crisis
item.description: A confrontation between the judiciary and the governing party will test Claudia Sheinbaum’s leadership and offer a window into how she will wield power.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico in Congress last month, after her swearing-in. Her party’s overhaul of the Mexican judiciary “will be an example to the world,” she has said.

item.title: Trump Had an ‘America First’ Foreign Policy. But It Was a Breakdown in American Policymaking.
item.description: A second Donald J. Trump presidency would almost certainly mark a return to an era of foreign policy decrees, untethered to any policy process, at a moment of maximum international peril.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: As president, Donald J. Trump was never a true isolationist, in spite of his rhetoric.

item.title: Friday Briefing: The Global Stakes of the U.S. Election
item.description: Plus, Japan's passion for the World Series.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta

item.title: U.S. Turns to China to Stop North Korean Troops From Fighting for Russia
item.description: American agencies have assessed that China dislikes the growing partnership between Russia and North Korea. The State Department has raised the troop issue with Chinese diplomats.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China and Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, in a photograph released by the Chinese state media. China is North Korea’s longtime ally and its most powerful economic and military partner.

item.title: ‘Witches’ Marks’? Curses? Medieval Etchings Uncovered at Manor House
item.description: A discovery of etched symbols and writing at a British Manor House has experts examining their possible meaning.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: Gainsborough Old Hall, where a “staggering array” of carved ritual protection or apotropaic marks were found, in Lincolnshire County, England.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: How the next U.S. administration may shape the world.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Bing Guan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Early voting is underway in many states.

item.title: Mexico Passes Bill Barring Legal Challenges to Constitutional Changes
item.description: The bill has drawn criticism from legal scholars who say it would bulldoze any judicial oversight of constitutional matters.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:description: Mexico City legislators rally in favor of a judicial overhaul at the Mexico City Congress in mid-September this year.

item.title: 8 Supreme Court Justices in Mexico to Resign Ahead of Contentious Election
item.description: All but three of the country’s Supreme Court justices announced they would quit rather than partake in the controversial elections mandated by a judicial overhaul.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: The Supreme Court building in Mexico City. Eight of the court’s 11 justices announced on Wednesday that they were resigning.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: U.S. Voters Focus on the Economy
item.description: Plus, what too much sugar does to your body.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta

item.title: Two Black Holes are Giving the Cosmos a Fright
item.description: The ghosts of stars are up to their usual mischief.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: Andrew Beardmore (Univ. of Leicester) and NASA/Swift

item.title: U.S. Says It Killed Islamic State Militants in Syria
item.description: Airstrikes on Monday targeted people who the military said were senior leaders of the group, which has sharply stepped up its attacks in Iraq and Syria.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: U.S. forces patrolling in Syria last month.

item.title: Flash Floods in Spain Kill at Least 158: What to Know
item.description: At least 158 people were killed after the downpour, which some residents said was the worst they had ever witnessed.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola, Isabella Kwai and José Bautista
item.media:description: Damaged vehicles lie in flood waters at an industrial complex in the province of Valencia, Spain.

item.title: Was This Scrap of Cloth Once a Tunic Worn by Alexander the Great?
item.description: A Greek researcher says a piece of purple-and-white fabric discovered decades ago in a tomb in northern Greece may have belonged to Alexander. Others disagree.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Nikolas Joao Kokovlis/SOPA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A statue of Alexander the Great in Athens. Antonis Bartsiokas, a paleoanthropologist, has claimed that fabric found in a tomb believed to have held the remains of Alexander’s father, Philip II, actually belonged to Alexander himself.

item.title: Israel Demolished Hundreds of Buildings in Southern Lebanon, Videos and Satellite Images Show
item.description: At least 1,085 buildings have been destroyed or badly damaged since Israel’s invasion targeting the Hezbollah militia, including many in controlled demolitions, a New York Times analysis shows.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert, Riley Mellen and Alexander Cardia

item.title: Fire Breaks Out at BAE’s UK Nuclear Submarine Plant
item.description: The authorities said there was no nuclear risk. Two people with smoke inhalation received treatment at a hospital.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: The entrance to the BAE Systems shipyard in Barrow-in-Furness, England.

item.title: Israel Orders Residents of Baalbek in Eastern Lebanon to Evacuate
item.description: Israel’s military warned civilians to leave Baalbek in the Bekaa Valley via three routes. The city had largely been spared Israeli bombardment until this week.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Christina Goldbaum and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Evacuating from Baalbek in eastern Lebanon on Wednesday.

item.title: Three Mile Island Is at the Center of Efforts to Expand Nuclear Capacity to Meet Rising Power Demand
item.description: The Pennsylvania plant, site of the worst U.S. nuclear energy accident, is at the forefront of efforts to expand nuclear capacity to meet rising electricity demand.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott and George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cooling towers at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania, where Constellation Energy plans to restart a reactor it shut down in 2019.

item.title: Some Geologists Argue Earth Has Fewer Than Seven Continents
item.description: Recent earth science developments suggest that how we count our planet’s largest land masses is less clear than we learned in school.
item.dc:creator: Matt Kaplan

item.title: Clean Energy Is Booming in the U.S. The Election Could Change That.
item.description: Trump has suggested he would dismantle the Inflation Reduction Act, which has reshaped America’s energy landscape. It won’t be easy.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Kristian Thacker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A battery manufacturing plant under construction at the site of a former steel mill in Weirton, W.Va.

item.title: Floods in Spain’s Valencia Region Kill at Least 95
item.description: About 1,000 soldiers from emergency response units deployed to the affected areas, and the death toll was expected to rise after one of the worst natural disasters to hit the country in recent years.
item.dc:creator: José Bautista, Isabella Kwai and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Víctor Fernández/Europa Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Members of emergency services and Guardia Civil rescue people trapped in their homes after floods in Letur, Albacete on Tuesday.

item.title: At a Glitzy Saudi Investment Forum, Almost No Mention of War
item.description: Saudi Arabia and its Gulf neighbors are seeking to reassure foreign investors that it’s still safe to do business amid the turmoil around the Mideast.
item.dc:creator: Ismaeel Naar
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
Abdulaziz bin Salman, Prince of Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: Yasir Al-Rumayyan, center, governor of Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, leads a round-table discussion at the kingdom’s annual investment conference, in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Can John Green Make You Care About Tuberculosis?
item.description: With a forthcoming nonfiction book and an online army of Nerdfighters, the young-adult author aims to eliminate an entirely curable global scourge.
item.dc:creator: Maddie Bender
item.media:credit: Lee Klafczynski for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Green, the best selling author and YouTuber, wants to bridge an “empathy gap” for tuberculosis, which disproportionately affects people in sub-Saharan Africa, Eastern Europe and Asia.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A closing address by Vice President Kamala Harris.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Kamala Harris

item.title: China’s Latest Security Target: Halloween Partygoers
item.description: Last year, the Shanghai government said Halloween celebrations were a sign of “cultural tolerance.” This year, the police rounded up people in costume.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Muyi Xiao

item.title: Satellite Images Suggest Israel Struck a Major Iranian Missile Plant
item.description: Analysts said the Shahroud Space Center was likely used to produce intermediate-range ballistic missiles that could be used to target Israel.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: A satellite image showing a large building at the Islamic Revolutionary Guards’ Shahroud Space Center in Iran in March.

item.title: What Are the Implications of Israel Banning UNRWA?
item.description: Humanitarian agencies fear the new Israeli laws could have catastrophic effects for Gazans. They are already drawing sharp criticism from Israel’s allies.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Palestinians lined up for medicine on Tuesday at an UNRWA health center in Khan Younis, Gaza, that operates with support from Japan, one of the U.N. agency’s top funders.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Trump’s Worrisome Business Deals
item.description: Plus, what happened to repatriated art in Benin.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta

item.title: Israeli Military Hits Gaza Town for 3rd Time in Days, Killing Dozens, Officials Say
item.description: Gazan agencies said that children were among those killed in the strike in Beit Lahia. A U.S. State Department spokesman called the strike “a horrifying incident with a horrifying result.”
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek, Rawan Sheikh Ahmad, Aaron Boxerman and Michael Levenson
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Palestinian emergency medical workers removing a body from the rubble of a building after an Israeli strike in Beit Lahia, in northern Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Family Members and Biden Aides Among China Hack Targets
item.description: Phones used by Jared Kushner and Eric Trump were among those that hackers sought access to as part of a counterintelligence effort carried out by a hacking group associated with China.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett, Ben Protess and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: Eric Trump was one of those believed to have been targeted by Chinese hackers.

item.title: Teen Accused in U.K. Taylor Swift Dance Class Stabbing Charged With Terror Offenses
item.description: The police said that they found Ricin and an Al Qaeda training manual in the suspect’s home. The attack on little girls at a Taylor Swift-themed event stoked anti-immigrant sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: A memorial event for the victims of the attack in Southport in August.

item.title: Parts of Spain Get a Month’s Worth of Rain in a Day
item.description: The deluge flooded streets, breached rivers and destroyed crops along the Mediterranean coast. There could be more rain still to come.
item.dc:creator: José Bautista and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Cars swept away by flood water in Alora, Spain, on Tuesday.

item.title: In Botswana’s Election, Diamond Profits Are a Defining Issue
item.description: The party that has governed the country since 1966 could lose power as the economy struggles from a slump in demand for diamonds, which made Botswana an African success story.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Yvonne Mooka
item.media:description: A diamond-processing plant in Gaborone, Botswana, last year.

item.title: The U.S. Army Prepares for War With China: New Vehicles, Face Paint and a 1,200-Foot Fall
item.description: The big and cumbersome Army is trying to transform itself to deploy quickly to Asia, if needed. It is an inherently dangerous business.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Kenny Holston
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Putin Oversees Nuclear Training Exercises at Delicate Moment for Ukraine War
item.description: The Russian leader’s emphasis on nuclear prowess has been seen as an attempt to deter Western military aid to Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin at the Kremlin in Moscow on Tuesday, in a photo released by Russian state media.

item.title: Dozens Killed in Israeli Strikes in Eastern Lebanon, Lebanese Officials Say
item.description: The barrage of Israeli airstrikes in the Bekaa Valley on Monday night killed at least 60 people, officials said. It appeared to be the deadliest attack in the area since the war escalated last month.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Jacob Roubai
item.media:description: Damage at the site of an overnight Israeli airstrike on the Gouraud Barracks neighborhood of Lebanon’s eastern city of Baalbek, in the vicinity of some ancient Roman ruins, on Tuesday.

item.title: Amid Climate Crisis, Svalbard Global Seed Vault Gets a Huge Deposit
item.description: A storage facility in Norway built to safeguard crop diversity recently received more than 30,000 samples as concerns grow about climate change and food insecurity.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Steffen Trumpf/Picture Alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Svalbard Global Seed Vault in Norway. The facility holds more than 1.3 million samples.

item.title: Vatican Issues First Report on Sex Abuse, to Immediate Criticism
item.description: The report is intended to assess efforts by the Roman Catholic Church to safeguard minors and others. Advocates for survivors called it an exercise in obfuscation.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis tasked the commission with verifying that countries were following a new church law that set out rules for reporting and combating clerical sexual abuse.

item.title: Hezbollah Names Naim Qassem as Its New Leader
item.description: Mr. Qassem had been the Lebanese militant group’s longtime deputy. He replaces Hassan Nasrallah, who was assassinated in an Israeli airstrike last month.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Naim Qassem at a memorial ceremony for senior Hezbollah commanders near Beirut, Lebanon, in June.

item.title: Zelensky, With Limited Options, Seeks a Path Forward for Ukraine
item.description: A muted response to Ukraine’s “victory plan” and steep challenges on the battlefield leave Kyiv searching for a Plan B.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker, Eric Schmitt, Steven Erlanger and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: The city of Siversk, Ukraine, remains under near-constant shelling from a Russian-occupied territory just to the east.

item.title: The Game Theory of Democracy
item.description: Countries where democracy is in trouble share a common pattern, and it’s a worrying one for the United States.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub

item.title: What Ants and Orcas Can Teach Us About Death
item.description: A philosopher journeys into the world of comparative thanatology, which explores how animals of all kinds respond to death and dying.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Gianfranco Tripodo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Susana Monsó, a philosopher of animal minds at the National Distance Education University in Madrid. “I’ve always been interested in those capacities that are understood to be uniquely human,” she said. “Death was a natural topic to pick up.”

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The comedian Tony Hinchcliffe has a history of racist jokes.
